worklogs.comment:
jorisvandenbossche commented on pull request #4601: ARROW-4847: [Python] Add pyarrow.table factory function
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4601
 
 
   Rudimentary implementation for https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-4847.
   
   For now I made the minimal choices:
   
   * Which formats to support? For now I only included DataFrame and dictionary, and not list of arrays or list of batches, because DataFrame/dictionary are most unambiguous and don't require additional keywords to be interpreted (eg list of arrays needs a list of names (or the schema)). 
     `from_batches` could probably easily be supported (eg by checking the first element of the list being a RecordBatch), but then it might also be nice to support a list of DataFrames to be interpreted as a list of batches? 
   
   * Which keywords to expose? For now I only included the keywords that are common to the different constructors being dispatched to (in practice only `schema`), in the idea you can always use the specialized constructors if needing more control.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

wesm commented on issue #4601: ARROW-4847: [Python] Add pyarrow.table factory function
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4601#issuecomment-503666255
 
 
   I would say to make `pa.table([a0, a1, a2], columns=['foo', 'bar', 'baz'])` (or `names`?) also work would be reasonable. `Table.from_pydict` does not have a names/columns argument (only schema), so this might be a good time to fix that

jorisvandenbossche commented on issue #4601: ARROW-4847: [Python] Add pyarrow.table factory function
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4601#issuecomment-503674803
 
 
   > I would say to make pa.table([a0, a1, a2], columns=['foo', 'bar', 'baz']) (or names?) also work would be reasonable
   
   pandas is treating such list of arrays as rows:
   
   ```
   In [11]: pd.DataFrame([np.array([1, 2, 3]), np.array([2, 3, 4])], columns=['a', 'b', 'c']) 
   Out[11]: 
      a  b  c
   0  1  2  3
   1  2  3  4
   ```
   
   which is not to say that is better / we can't deviate from it, but IMO it certainly indicates that it might not be obvious what the behaviour will be.
   
   > Table.from_pydict does not have a names/columns argument (only schema), so this might be a good time to fix that
   
   What would that argument do? (since the dict already has names in it) To select a subset from the dictionary, or to provide a specific order of the columns? 
   It might also be interpreted as overwriting the names from the dict (which I would not do, as that would rely on the order of the dict). Although you could say the same for the `schema` argument of course.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

jorisvandenbossche commented on issue #4601: ARROW-4847: [Python] Add pyarrow.table factory function
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4601#issuecomment-503676534
 
 
   > Although you could say the same for the schema argument of course.
   
   Good that I check. This is actually buggy. It is "kind of" overwriting the names of the dictionary, but without properly doing type conversion:
   
   ```
   In [15]: table = pa.Table.from_pydict(
       ...:     {'a': [1, 2, 3], 'b': [3, 4, 5]},
       ...:     schema=pa.schema([('a', pa.int64()), ('c', pa.int32())]))
   In [16]: table                                                                                                                                                                                                     
   Out[16]: 
   pyarrow.Table
   a: int64
   c: int32
   
   In [17]: table.to_pandas()                                                                                                                                                                                         
   Out[17]: 
      a  c
   0  1  3
   1  2  0
   2  3  4
   ```
   
   So I am passing a schema with different names, but also with a non-default type (int32 vs int64), and the values in the column are probably first converted as int64 but then viewed as int32 instead of casted (or rather, instead of being converted directly to int32 in the first place).
   
   Will open a JIRA for this.
   
   
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

jorisvandenbossche commented on issue #4601: ARROW-4847: [Python] Add pyarrow.table factory function
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4601#issuecomment-503676534
 
 
   > Although you could say the same for the schema argument of course.
   
   Good that I check. This is actually buggy. It is "kind of" overwriting the names of the dictionary, but without properly doing type conversion:
   
   ```
   In [15]: table = pa.Table.from_pydict(
       ...:     {'a': [1, 2, 3], 'b': [3, 4, 5]},
       ...:     schema=pa.schema([('a', pa.int64()), ('c', pa.int32())]))
   
   In [16]: table
   Out[16]: 
   pyarrow.Table
   a: int64
   c: int32
   
   In [17]: table.to_pandas()
   Out[17]: 
      a  c
   0  1  3
   1  2  0
   2  3  4
   ```
   
   So I am passing a schema with different names, but also with a non-default type (int32 vs int64), and the values in the column are probably first converted as int64 but then viewed as int32 instead of casted (or rather, instead of being converted directly to int32 in the first place).
   
   Will open a JIRA for this. UPDATE -> https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-5655

pitrou commented on pull request #4601: ARROW-4847: [Python] Add pyarrow.table factory function
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4601#discussion_r297199224
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/table.pxi
 ##########
 @@ -1570,6 +1570,35 @@ def _reconstruct_table(arrays, schema):
     return Table.from_arrays(arrays, schema=schema)
 
 
+def table(data, schema=None):
+    """
+    Create a pyarrow.Table from a Python object (table like objects such as
+    DataFrame, dictionary).
+
+    Parameters
+    ----------
+    data : pandas.DataFrame, dict
+        A DataFrame or a mapping of strings to Arrays or Python lists.
+    schema : Schema, default None
+        The expected schema of the Arrow Table. If not passed, will be
+        inferred from the data.
+
+    Returns
+    -------
+    Table
+
+    See Also
+    --------
+    Table.from_pandas, Table.from_pydict
+    """
+    if isinstance(data, dict):
+        return Table.from_pydict(data, schema=schema)
+    elif isinstance(data, _pandas_api.pd.DataFrame):
+        return Table.from_pandas(data, schema=schema)
+    else:
+        return ValueError("Expected pandas DataFrame or python dictionary")
 
 Review comment:
   `TypeError` preferably.

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4601#issuecomment-505675369
 
 
   +1. @jorisvandenbossche if you would please use `git rebase` instead of `git merge` in this project, it eases maintenance for us since we are rebase-centric here.
   
   I'll open a follow up JIRA about adding support for `Table.from_arrays` to this function

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description: For example, in {{pyarrow.table(df)}} if {{df}} is a {{pandas.DataFrame}}, then table will dispatch to {{pa.Table.from_pandas}}
fields.summary: [Python] Add pyarrow.table factory function that dispatches to various ctors based on type of input
